title.justification: It is the exact title mentioned in the paper.

extractions.description: An empirical study on the effects of batch size in value-based deep reinforcement learning, finding that smaller batch sizes can significantly improve performance and computational efficiency.

type.justification: The paper presents a broad empirical study, conducts evaluations with multiple agents, and provides experimental results.
type.quote: In this work we present a broad empirical study that suggests reducing the batch size can result in a number of significant performance gains

name.justification: The study focuses on value-based deep reinforcement learning and its dynamics.
name.quote: In this work we conduct a broad empirical study of batch size in online value-based deep reinforcement learning.

name.justification: The key focus of the study is to understand the impact of batch size on performance in deep reinforcement learning.
name.quote: Surprisingly, to the best of our knowledge there have been no studies exploring the impact of the choice of batch size in deep RL.

name.justification: It is specified as one of the agents used in the experiments for the 100k benchmark.
name.quote: Data-efficient Rainbow (DER), a version of the Rainbow algorithm with hyper-parameters tuned for faster early learning; DrQ(ε), which is a variant of DQN that uses data augmentation; and SPR.

name.justification: It is one of the agents used to evaluate the impact of reduced batch sizes.
name.quote: Self-Predictive Representation (SPR), which incorporates self-supervised learning to improve sample efficiency.

name.justification: The paper mentions using a 'compact' version of the original Rainbow algorithm.
name.quote: Rainbow [Note that Dopamine uses a 'compact' version of the original Rainbow agent, including only multi-step updates, prioritized replay, and C51].

name.justification: The paper describes the use of the 100k benchmark for evaluating Atari agents with very few environment interactions.
name.quote: There has been an increased interest in evaluating Atari agents on very few environment interactions, for which Kaiser et al. [2020] proposed the 100k benchmark .

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions using the standard set of 26 games for the 100k benchmark evaluation.
name.quote: In Figure 4 we include results both at the 100k benchmark and when trained for 30 million frames. For this evaluation we evaluate on the standard 26 games for this benchmark.

name.justification: The authors acknowledge the use of NumPy for array programming, which enabled the research.
name.quote: We also acknowledge the Python community for developing tools that enabled this work, including NumPy.

name.justification: The authors acknowledge the use of Matplotlib for 2D graphics, which aided the research.
name.quote: We also acknowledge the Python community for developing tools that enabled this work, including Matplotlib.
